articles.headline: As States Weigh Online Gambling, Profit May Be Small
articles.snippet: Raising revenue remains the draw for most, but some wonder whether profits from Internet play would make any significant differences to deficits.
articles.abstract: Raising revenue remains the draw for most, but some wonder whether profits from Internet play would make any significant differences to deficits.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been more than four decades since states began putting numbers runners out of business by starting their own legal lotteries, which now yield them close to $18 billion a year. Now several states are thinking about trying to plug budget gaps by profiting again from their residents’ optimism — by legalizing, licensing and taxing Internet gambling.

articles.headline: Romney Shares Some Tax Data; Critics Pounce
articles.snippet: Under renewed pressure to release his personal income tax returns, Mitt Romney said that he paid a tax rate approaching 15 percent.
articles.abstract: Under renewed pressure to release his personal income tax returns, Mitt Romney said that he paid a tax rate approaching 15 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Under growing pressure from rival Republicans to release his tax returns, Mitt Romney said on Tuesday that he paid a tax rate approaching 15 percent on his millions of dollars in annual income but said he would not make public his full return until April.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore, David Kocieniewski and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: As European Union Beckons, Allure Fades for Wary Croatia
articles.snippet: Croatians are set to vote on joining the organization, which has become mired in a debt crisis that threatens its very essence in the decade since the country first applied for membership.
articles.abstract: Croatians are set to vote on joining the organization, which has become mired in a debt crisis that threatens its very essence in the decade since the country first applied for membership.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARMICA, Croatia — Zoran Sluga has a small family farm here on the border with Slovenia, his 300-year-old barn filled with thousands of squawking chickens.
articles.byline: By Suzanne Daley and Stephen Castle

articles.headline: In Tech, Starting Up by Failing
articles.snippet: Entrepreneurs are finding that many investors will keep the money flowing even when an unsuccessful start-up decides to take an entirely new direction.
articles.abstract: Entrepreneurs are finding that many investors will keep the money flowing even when an unsuccessful start-up decides to take an entirely new direction.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every entrepreneur hopes to start the next big thing. But sometimes the first try doesn’t go as planned.

articles.headline: Young, in Love and Sharing Everything, Including a Password
articles.snippet: Young people are expressing their affection by swapping passwords to e-mail, Facebook and other accounts.
articles.abstract: Young people are expressing their affection by swapping passwords to e-mail, Facebook and other accounts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Young couples have long signaled their devotion to each other by various means — the gift of a letterman jacket, or an exchange of class rings or ID bracelets. Best friends share locker combinations.

articles.headline: Industry Weighs Effect of Ship Accident
articles.snippet: Shares of the Carnival Corporation fell 14 percent on Tuesday, and analysts said the accident in Italy could not have happened at a worse time for the industry.
articles.abstract: Shares of the Carnival Corporation fell 14 percent on Tuesday, and analysts said the accident in Italy could not have happened at a worse time for the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shares of the Carnival Corporation, the world’s largest cruise ship operator, fell 14 percent on Tuesday as analysts and investors sought to gauge the effect of the grounding of Carnival’s Costa Concordia after days of continual images and videos of the listing ship.

articles.headline: A Political Coming of Age for the Tech Industry
articles.snippet: With a Web-wide protest on Wednesday that includes a shutdown of Wikipedia, the legislative battle over two piracy bills has reached a political coming of age.
articles.abstract: With a Web-wide protest on Wednesday that includes a shutdown of Wikipedia, the legislative battle over two piracy bills has reached a political coming of age.
articles.lead_paragraph: With a Web-wide protest on Wednesday that includes a 24-hour shutdown of the English-language Wikipedia, the legislative battle over two Internet piracy bills has reached an extraordinary moment — a political coming of age for a relatively young and disorganized industry that has largely steered clear of lobbying and other political games in Washington.
